title: Why Paul Little is switching from property to angel investing
text:
"The experience offshore has proven some amazing companies evolve out of this seed and start-up area ... we see our initial playground as Victoria but we see us being able to grow out of Victoria to Australia and become regionally dominant."

The fund is being financially backed by the board, which includes RBA and Stockland director Carol Schwartz, Intrepid co-founder Darrell Wade, Lochard co-founder Martin Adams and Swinburne vice-chancellor Linda Kristjanson.

"If we're serious about wanting to nurture an entrepreneurial culture in Australia, then a critical part of the ecosystem is the angel investor – those individuals and organisations that are willing to take a risk and back a tranformational, new idea," Ms Schwartz told the Financial Review.

Carol Schwartz is part of the Skalata Ventures board and says angel investing is critical.

Skalata CEO and co-founder Rohan Workman said seed investing in the US was returning up to 27 per cent per annum and "we think a lot of the conditions in Australia are similar to the US".

Major venture capital funds like AirTree, Square Peg and Blackbird typically aren't prepared to invest less than $1 million and would prefer to invest $3 million to $5 million, as super funds such as AustralianSuper are also moving into that space.

"As people start making investments they tend to move up the value chain because they can deploy more capital, the risk is less and it is also hard work doing seed investing," Mr Workman said.

"The issue is if you don't have a vibrant seed or angel community, there is less deal flow for venture capitalists."

Advertisement

Ms Schwartz and Mr Little agreed "angel investing was about more than the money" and pointed to research from the Office of the Chief Economist in 2015 which found companies in their first five years contribute disproportionately to job creation.

Mr Workman added the mentoring and networks the fund provided were also as important as the capital.

"One area where we can improve is providing not just the capital but the knowledge and the networks required for companies to get through that stage post start-up but pre-venture capital," he said.

Shane Thatcher and Sonya Stephen, creators of the Choovie app. Joe Armao

Mr Little said he had discovered angel investing "is a numbers game" with only one start-up in 10, 20 or even 30 qualifying as a success.

"Not every company you invest in is going to give you a return and I think with these early stage companies it is pretty well understood it's a numbers game," he said.

In June, the fund selected its first nine start-ups into their bespoke six-month program which is customised for each company, offering operational support and mentoring from Skalata's network of investors, prospective customers and advisers.

It plans to take on 60 start-ups over its first three years with up to $250,000 in funding provided to each.

Advertisement

The cohort included SmartPaddock, which makes cattle ear tag monitors; Choovie, which attempts to monetise the 83 per cent of cinema seats left vacant; and KeyNinja, a platform for Airbnb hosts to securely provide their guests access and reduce fraud and property damage.

Mr Workman, the former director of the Melbourne Accelerator Program, said "he couldn't pick between his children" but highlighted SmartPaddock.

Mr Little also said Gamyra, which is developing driving simulation technology, "is exciting because that has come out of Williams F1 and now with my involvement running the Grand Prix Corporation".

"But I actually like the one [Hearables 3D] modelling earphones. It uses 3D printing for custom fitted headphones ... they send off the scan and get your earphones that afternoon ... then they can move down to teeth and other body parts."
description: Melbourne billionaire Paul Little is ramping-up his switch from investing in property to early stage start-ups because he sees a big gap in the market.
